name: DSA by striver
description: Comprehensive Data Structures and Algorithms course by Striver covering fundamentals to advanced topics

topics.name: Language Basics (12/12)
topics.description: Core programming fundamentals and language syntax essentials
learningTip: Master the fundamentals - they're the foundation of everything
Variables, loops, conditionals, functions should be automatic
Understand time complexity from the start
Practice typing code without IDE autocomplete
mustNotMiss: Primitive types: int, float, char, boolean and their ranges
Loops: for, while, do-while - know when to use each
Functions: parameters, return values, scope
Arrays: declaration, indexing, traversal

topics.name: Logic Building (Patterns) (2/2)
topics.description: Building logical thinking through pattern problems
learningTip: Patterns help you visualize nested loops
Draw the pattern on paper first, identify the relationship
Outer loop = rows, inner loop = columns
Notice: which variable changes faster?
mustNotMiss: Understand relationship between row number and content
Spaces + stars often equal a constant (like row count)
Inner loop bounds often depend on outer loop variable
Practice until you can write any pattern without hesitation

topics.name: Patterns (8/22)
topics.description: Classic coding patterns for interviews
learningTip: Each pattern teaches a specific loop relationship
Master the relationship between i and j in nested loops
Pyramid, diamond, number patterns - all use same concepts
Speed and accuracy come from practice
mustNotMiss: Row i often determines: spaces, characters, or numbers
Common patterns: right triangle, inverted, pyramid, diamond
Think in terms of: leading spaces, middle content, trailing spaces
Most patterns have O(n²) time complexity

topics.name: Time Complexity (0/1)
topics.description: Analyzing algorithm efficiency with Big-O notation
learningTip: Big-O describes worst-case growth rate, not exact time
Drop constants and lower-order terms: O(3n² + 2n) = O(n²)
Nested loops often multiply: O(n) inside O(n) = O(n²)
Look at the input size constraints to choose algorithm
mustNotMiss: O(1) < O(log n) < O(n) < O(n log n) < O(n²) < O(2^n)
For n=10^6, you need O(n) or O(n log n) to fit in time limit
Space complexity: how much extra memory do you need?
Recursive calls add to space (call stack)

topics.name: STL and Collections (0/2)
topics.description: Important DSA topic for interview preparation
learningTip: Understand the pattern, not just the solution
Focus on recognizing problem types
Practice until implementation is automatic
Analyze time and space complexity for every solution
mustNotMiss: Always check edge cases: empty input, single element
Understand time/space tradeoffs
Be able to explain your approach clearly
Practice dry-running your code mentally

topics.name: Sum of Array Elements
topics.description: Calculate the sum of all elements in an array
learningTip: Foundation of accumulation pattern
Initialize sum = 0, add each element
Same pattern for: product, count, average
O(n) time, O(1) space
mustNotMiss: let sum = 0; for(const num of arr) sum += num;
Or: arr.reduce((sum, num) => sum + num, 0)
Watch for integer overflow with large arrays
Edge cases: empty array returns 0

topics.name: Reverse an array
topics.description: Reverse the elements of an array in place
learningTip: Two-pointer approach: swap from ends toward middle
In-place means O(1) extra space
Key insight: you only iterate half the array
Pattern applies to: palindrome check, string reversal
mustNotMiss: Two pointers: left = 0, right = arr.length - 1
While left < right: swap, move both
Original array is modified (in-place)
Stop when pointers meet or cross

topics.name: Selection Sort
topics.description: Selection sort algorithm implementation and analysis
learningTip: Find minimum, swap to current position, repeat
Simple but inefficient: O(n²) always
Minimizes swaps compared to bubble sort
Good for understanding sorting concepts
mustNotMiss: For i: find min in unsorted portion, swap with position i
Inner loop: j from i+1 to n-1
Always O(n²) - doesn't adapt to sorted input
Use for small arrays or when swaps are expensive

topics.name: Bubble Sort
topics.description: Bubble sort algorithm implementation and analysis
learningTip: Largest element 'bubbles up' each pass
Compare adjacent, swap if out of order
Can optimize with 'swapped' flag
O(n²) worst case, O(n) best case if optimized
mustNotMiss: Compare arr[j] with arr[j+1], swap if needed
After pass i, last i elements are sorted
Optimization: if no swaps in a pass, array is sorted
Stable sort: equal elements maintain order

topics.name: Insertion Sorting
topics.description: Insertion sort algorithm implementation and analysis
learningTip: Understand the pattern, not just the solution
Focus on recognizing problem types
Practice until implementation is automatic
Analyze time and space complexity for every solution
mustNotMiss: Always check edge cases: empty input, single element
Understand time/space tradeoffs
Be able to explain your approach clearly
Practice dry-running your code mentally

topics.name: Merge Sorting
topics.description: Merge sort algorithm implementation and analysis
learningTip: Divide array in half, recursively sort, merge
Merge step: combine two sorted arrays efficiently
Guaranteed O(n log n) - no bad input exists
Master this: it's a key D&C pattern
mustNotMiss: Divide: split at mid = Math.floor((left + right) / 2)
Merge: use two pointers for two sorted halves
Space: O(n) for temporary merge array
Stable: equal elements preserve original order

topics.name: Quick Sorting
topics.description: Quick sort algorithm implementation and analysis
learningTip: Choose pivot, partition: smaller left, larger right
Average O(n log n), worst O(n²) with bad pivot
In-place: O(log n) stack space
Key interview sort: know it cold
mustNotMiss: Partition: elements < pivot go left, >= go right
Pivot ends in final sorted position after partition
Randomized pivot avoids worst case
In-place but not stable
